Calyculi 0; phyllaries in 1–7+ series; disc cypselae seldom obcompressed or 4-angled and linear-fusiform (usually not winged).
Phyllaries falling together with cypselae (plus 2 contiguous disc florets and their invest- ing paleae)
Phyllaries persistent (in fruit).
Receptacles columnar
Receptacles mostly flat to convex or conic.
Leaves basal and cauline, mostly alternate; pappi usually fragile or readily falling
Leaves usually cauline and opposite, sometimes mostly basal and/or mostly alternate; pappi usually persistent (readily falling in Melanthera ).
Disc corollas lavender, pink, purple, or white; anther thecae cream or purple
Disc corollas usually orange to yellow, sometimes brown, pink, purple, red, or white; anther thecae pale or dark (not violet).
Stigmatic papillae in 2 lines.
Paleae conduplicate (each ± clasping a cypsela)
Pappi of 5–8 linear-lanceolate, erose-margined scales
Pappi of 15–25+ plumose, setiform scales
Paleae subulate or setiform (not conduplicate and each clasping a cypsela).
Corollas white, pinkish, cream, or yellow; cypselae clavate to ± cylindric or compressed, obscurely 8–20-angled; pappi of (1–)4–20, ± erose scales in 1–4 series

Corollas yellow or orange to red, purplish, or brown; cypselae obpyramidal to clavate, ± 4-angled; pappi of 6–10+ medially thickened, laterally scarious scales in 1–2 series (all, some, or none aristate)
Stigmatic papillae usually continuous, sometimes none (functionally staminate florets), rarely in 2 lines.
Leaves mostly cauline, mostly opposite.
Corollas white or whitish; pappi readily falling, of 2–12 barbellate awns (or bristles)

Corollas yellow to orange; pappi usually persistent and coroniform or cyathiform (each an erose, fimbriate, or lacerate cup, with or without additional awns or bristles, borne on rostra), or of 2–4+ awns and/or scales.
Pappi usually of 2–3 (often aristate or subulate) scales (not cyathiform; cypselae not rostrate)
Pappi usually cyathiform (fimbriate cups plus 0–3 coarse bristles or awns, borne on rostra; cypselae often rostrate)
Leaves mostly basal, or basal and cauline, or cauline, mostly alternate.
Cypselae winged; pappi of 2(–3) scales (scales often aristate or subulate, without additional scales)

Cypselae sometimes thin-edged (margins sometimes ciliate or corky-thickened, never truly winged); pappi usually of (1–)2, subulate scales or bristlelike awns plus 2–4+ shorter scales (rarely of 2–3, aristate scales without additional scales).
Subshrubs or shrubs (glabrous or ± scabrellous, usually vernicose); phyllaries 12–40 in 2– 4+ series (subequal or unequal, outer longer)

Annuals, perennials, or shrubs (glabrous or canescent, hirtellous, scabrellous, strigose, or tomentose, often gland-dotted or glandular-puberulent to stipitate-glandular, seldom vernicose); phyllaries 18–30(–-50+) in 2–3+ series (subequal or unequal, outer shorter).
Perennials ( E. nutans ), subshrubs, or shrubs; pappi sometimes fragile, of 2 weak, bristlelike (villous) scales
Annuals or perennials; pappi usually persistent, of 2 awns or subulate scales
Cypselae usually polymorphic within heads (straight, arcuate, contorted, or ± coiled), sometimes ± beaked (bodies usually tuberculate, ridged, and/or winged, sometimes drupelike).
Shrubs or trees; cypselae fleshy (drupelike)
Annuals, perennials, or shrubs; cypselae not fleshy (often tuberculate or ridged and/or winged).
Disc florets bisexual (some or all fertile)
Disc florets all functionally staminate.
Cypselae arcuate to ± coiled, abaxially tuberculate, sometimes winged
Cypselae triquetrous-prismatic to clavate, ± tuberculate and/or winged
Cypselae usually monomorphic, sometimes dimorphic, within heads, rarely, if ever, beaked (bodies smooth, papillate, muricate, ribbed, nerved, or rugulose, sometimes winged).

Margins of leaf blades usually 1–3-palmately or -pinnately lobed (ultimate lobes usually linear to filiform), sometimes dentate or entire; phyllaries in (2–)3–5+ series, unequal, and scarious or margins and/or apices notably scarious.
Subshrubs or shrubs (plants often persisting after cultivation)
Annuals.
Stems and leaves hirtellous to pilosulous (some hairs gland-tipped, plants sticky, viscid)
Stems and leaves glabrous or hairy (hairs not gland-tipped, plants not viscid).
Rays proximally white or red to purple, distally yellow or white; disc corollas proximally ochroleucous, distally red to purple (phyllaries ± carinate)
Rays mostly white (usually yellowish at bases) or mostly yellow (sometimes paler distally); disc corollas ± yellow (phyllaries not carinate).
Involucres 8–12(–15+) mm diam.; rays white (usually yellowish at bases, drying pinkish), laminae oblong to ovate (6–12+ mm); disc corolla lobes (2–)5 (without resin sacs)
Involucres 15–25+ mm diam.; rays mostly yellow, sometimes paler distally, laminae linear, oblong, or ovate (8–25 mm); disc corolla lobes 5 (each with a resin sac)
Cypselae ± monomorphic, outer and inner similar (none notably winged).
Annuals.
Leaves usually irregularly 1-pinnately lobed or toothed; involucres ± hemispheric, 8–12(–15+) mm diam.; disc florets 60–100+; cypsela ribs 7–10
Leaves (1–)2–3-pinnately lobed; involucres 4–14 mm diam.; disc florets 120–750+; cypsela ribs 3–5.
Cypselae obconic, slightly compressed (usually asymmetric, apices oblique), ribs 5, faces smooth between ribs (pericarps without resin sacs, or resin sacs within lateral ribs)

Cypselae trigonous, ± compressed, ribs 3–5 (0–2 abaxial, 2 lateral, 1 adaxial, usually whitish, relatively thick, smooth), faces smooth or rugose to tuberculate between ribs (pericarps usually with 2–3, sometimes 1–5 mostly abaxial-apical, resin sacs)
Biennials or perennials.
Heads usually in lax to dense, corymbiform arrays, rarely borne singly; pappi usually coroniform, rarely 0
Heads usually borne singly or in 2s or 3s, sometimes in corymbiform arrays; pappi usually 0, sometimes crowns of 6–12 irregular teeth.
Ray florets styliferous and sterile
Ray florets pistillate and fertile.

Cypselae trigonous, ± compressed, ribs 3–5 (0–2 abaxial, 2 lateral, 1 adaxial, usually whitish, relatively thick, smooth), faces smooth or rugose to tuberculate between ribs (pericarps usually with 2–3, sometimes 1–5 mostly abaxial-apical, resin sacs)
Cypselae ± columnar, cylindro-obconic, or obovoid, ribs 5–10 (pericarps without apical resin sacs).
Plants (10–)50–130(–200+) cm; disc corolla tubes ± cylindric (proximally swollen, becoming spongy in fruit); cypselae ± columnar to obovoid, ribs ± 10 (pericarps with myxogenic cells)
Plants mostly (2.5–)5–40 cm; disc corolla tubes ± cylindric (not swollen, not becoming spongy in fruit); cypselae cylindro-obconic, ribs 5–8(–10) (pericarps without myxogenic cells).
Leaf margins entire; involucres 4–6.5 mm diam.; phyllaries 20–26(+) in 2(–3+) series (receptacles ± villous)
Leaf margins usually pinnati-palmately lobed (lobes 3–7), ultimate margins coarsely crenate, dentate, or entire; involucres 13–29 mm diam.; phyllaries 22–44 in 3(–4) series (receptacles glabrous)

Margins of leaf blades entire, dentate, lobed, palmatifid, pinnatifid, or dissected (ultimate lobes sometimes linear to filiform); phyllaries in 1–2 series and ± equal to subequal, or in 3–8+ series and unequal, usually herbaceous to chartaceous, sometimes with margins and/or apices notably scarious.

Leaves alternate; phyllaries in 1–2 series and equal to subequal (sometimes coherent, often subtended by calyculi); style-branch appendages usually penicillate or essentially none; cypselae usually ± columnar to prismatic, seldom compressed, obcompressed, or flattened.
Perennials.
Rays usually whitish or bluish, pinkish, purplish, or reddish (often proximally pale and distally darker); disc floret style-branches: stigmatic areas in 2 lines
Rays yellow; disc floret style-branches: stigmatic areas continuous
Annuals.
Disc florets bisexual (fertile, styles 2-branched); leaf blades spatulate or oblanceolate to lanceolate or linear, margins toothed or entire, faces glabrous or glabrate

Leaves whorled, opposite, or alternate; phyllaries in 1–2 series and subequal, or in 3–6+ series and unequal; style-branch appendages usually deltate to lanceolate, seldom penicillate or none; cypselae sometimes compressed, obcompressed, or flattened.
Leaves opposite (at least proximally).
Leaves and/or phyllaries dotted or streaked with pellucid (schizogenous) glands containing strong-scented (lemon or spicy) oils; ray florets borne on bases of subtending phyllaries

Leaves and/or phyllaries rarely dotted or streaked (never with pellucid, schizogenous glands containing strong-scented oils, plants sometimes with sessile or stipitate, surface glands and may be otherwise strong-scented); ray florets borne on receptacles.
Leaves (often ± succulent) sessile or nearly so, blades usually oblong to linear or filiform (not lobed); cypselae clavate to cylindric and 8–15-ribbed.
Heads in tight, corymbiform aggregations or arrays; phyllaries 2–6(–9) in ± 1 series, subequal; rays 1(–2)
Heads borne singly; phyllaries 12–15 in 3+ series, unequal; rays 3–10

Leaves (seldom succulent) petiolate or sessile, blades often lobed; cypselae usually obpyramidal to obconic, sometimes columnar or flattened, seldom clavate or cylindric, often 4–5-angled (not both clavate to cylindric and 8–15-ribbed; sometimes cylindric and 5–10-nerved).
Phyllaries often ± conduplicate and navicular; disc corollas 4-lobed; cypselae strongly flattened to subcylindric, ± callous-margined, often ciliate

Phyllaries usually flat to weakly navicular; disc corollas (4–)5-lobed; cypselae narrowly clavate or columnar to obconic or obpyramidal (not strongly compressed or flattened, callous-margined, and ciliate).
Leaves usually sessile, sometimes obscurely petiolate, blades (or lobes) linear, margins entire or 1–2-pinnately lobed

Leaves usually petiolate, sometimes sessile, blades rounded-deltate or cordate to ovate, narrowly trullate, lanceolate, linear, obovate, oblanceolate, or cuneate to spatulate, margins entire, toothed, or distally 3-lobed (not 1–2-pinnately lobed).
Phyllaries 20–40+ in 3–4+ series; rays 12–34, yellow
Phyllaries 5–18 in 1–3 series; rays 5–12, yellow, or white or pinkish with reddish veins.

Leaf blades either linear and margins entire, or narrowly cuneate to spatulate and margins usually distally 3-lobed; phyllaries 5–8 in 1 series; rays either yellow, or white or pinkish with reddish veins
Blades lanceolate, narrowly trullate, oblanceolate, obovate, margins entire or denticulate; phyllaries 5–18 in 1–3 series; rays yellow.
Phyllaries 5–12 in 1 series
Phyllaries 14–18 in ± 3 series
Leaves alternate or mostly alternate (sometimes proximal opposite).
Rays white, pink, purple, or blue.
Receptacles conic.
Leaves usually pinnatifid to dentate, sometimes entire; rays without midstripe abaxially; cypselae not or slightly compressed.
Plants gland-dotted; cypselae oblong to narrowly obovoid, slightly compressed, 2-nerved, sometimes gland-dotted
Plants eglandular; cypselae columnar to prismatic, usually 4-angled, 4–12-ribbed (ribs relatively thick), eglandular
Leaves usually entire, sometimes ± toothed; rays usually with pink or purplish midstripe abaxially; cypselae strongly compressed or flattened.

Perennials 5–20 cm (short-rhizomatous); leaves mostly basal, margins entire or crenate-serrate; rays 35–90 in 3–4 series (closing at night); cypselae obconic, glabrous to short-strigose or ciliate-margined
Receptacles flat to convex.
Leaves mostly basal or basal and cauline, margins 1–2-pinnately lobed (lobes usually filiform); rays 8, white; cypselae obpyramidal (4- or 5-angled, faces 1–4-ribbed)

Leaves basal (usually withering by flowering) or mostly cauline, margins entire or toothed, sometimes 1-pinnately lobed (lobes not usually filiform); rays (1–)3–70, white or pink to blue or purple; cypselae linear, fusiform, clavate, oblanceoloid, obovoid, or obconic, ± flattened or ± compressed to ± cylindric, sometimes 2–18-nerved.
Phyllaries 5–8 in 1 series, subequal; rays white or pinkish with reddish veins
Phyllaries 5–50 in 2–6 series, equal to unequal; rays white or blue to purple (not with reddish veins).
Disc corolla lobes 4
Disc corolla lobes 5.
Heads borne singly (terminal); phyllaries in 2–3 series, equal to subequal, faces eglandular
Heads in loose, corymbiform arrays; phyllaries in 2–6 series, unequal, (herbaceous) faces stipitate-glandular
Rays usually yellow to orange, sometimes red.
Disc corollas usually 4-lobed; cypselae usually callous-margined and ciliate
Disc corollas 5-lobed; cypselae not callous-margined or notably ciliate.
Subshrubs or shrubs.
Heads (± sessile) in compact glomerules (glomerules densely clustered in terminal, corymbiform arrays); involucres 1.5–2 mm diam.; rays 4–6; disc florets 4– 6
Heads (± pedunculate) borne singly or in corymbiform to paniculiform arrays (not in glomerules); involucres 5–25 mm diam.; rays 5–60+; disc florets 20–300.
Phyllaries in 5–8+ series, apices (terete to filiform or subulate) recurved or straight, or looped to hooked or patent
Phyllaries in 1–4 series, apices usually straight, not recurved, looped, hooked, or patent.
Leaf blades usually 1–2(–3)-pinnately lobed, ultimate margins entire or toothed, faces ± woolly; involucres campanulate to hemispheric, 3–12+ mm diam.; phyllaries in 1+ series (sometimes ± connate)

Leaf blades rounded-deltate or cordate to ovate, entire or toothed, abaxial faces puberulent or gland-dotted; involucres hemispheric to globose, 12–25+ mm diam.; phyllaries in 3–4 series (outer rotund to oblong, herbaceous-foliaceous)
Annuals, biennials, or perennials.
Ray florets usually neuter, rarely pistillate and fertile or styliferous and sterile (disc corolla lobes often shaggily hairy, hairs ± moniliform)
Ray florets pistillate, fertile.
Ray florets in 2 series (staminodes often present), adaxial faces of inner laminae marked basally with purple-brown fans 1 / 4 – 1 / 8 their lengths
Ray florets in 1 series (without staminodes), adaxial faces of laminae not marked basally with purple-brown.
Phyllaries 25–100+ in (3–)4–9+ series, apices (terete to filiform or subulate) recurved or straight, or looped to hooked or patent
Phyllaries 5–40 in 1–4 series, apices usually straight, not recurved, looped, hooked, or patent.
Leaf blades simple, margins entire, spinulose-toothed, or sinuate-dentate (not lobed).
Phyllaries 30–40 in 2–4 series (annuals; leaf blades oblanceolate, margins entire or spinulose-toothed, faces glabrous, gland-dotted; rays 14– 63)
Phyllaries 2–34 in 1–2(–3) series.
Leaf blades linear to lanceolate, margins entire; disc florets 10–21, functionally staminate
Leaf blades narrowly oblong, oblanceolate, or lance-linear, margins sinuate-dentate or entire; disc florets 10–100+, bisexual, fertile.

Leaf blades narrowly oblong, oblanceolate, or lance-linear, margins sinuate-dentate or entire; heads usually borne singly (sometimes in corymbiform arrays); phyllaries in 1 series, distinct; cypselae obcompressed or ± prismatic, 2–4-angled

Leaf blades lance-linear to broadly ovate, margins entire; heads borne singly or in cymiform arrays; phyllaries in 2 series, distinct or connate; cypselae narrowly obpyramidal, weakly ribbed or striate
Leaf blades 1–2(–3)-pinnately or -ternately lobed, pinnatifid, or distally 3-lobed.
Phyllaries in 1 series.
Leaf blades distally 3-lobed
Leaf blades usually 1–2(–3)-pinnately lobed.
Ray cypselae obcompressed (disc corollas with rings of hairs at bases of limbs)
Ray cypselae usually prismatic, 4–5-angled (disc corollas with- out rings of hairs)
Phyllaries in 2–3+ series.
Cypselae obpyramidal (lengths usually 3+ times diams.)
Cypselae stoutly obconic to obpyramidal (lengths usually 1–2, rarely to 3.5 times diams.).
Phyllary margins usually notably membranous to scarious; disc corollas usually whitish, sometimes purplish or yellowish; cypselae usually 4-angled and 12–16-ribbed
Phyllary margins seldom scarious; disc corollas yellow or partly yellow-brown proximally; cypselae sometimes weakly ribbed or striate (not both 4-angled and 12–16-ribbed).
Receptacles usually hemispheric, globoid, ovoid, conic (seldom flat); ray florets 3–16 (corollas withering, falling early or tardily)
Receptacles flat to convex; ray florets usually 5–7 or 20– 55 (corollas usually marcescent)
Cauline leaves opposite (at least proximal).
Leaves sessile; leaves and phyllaries dotted with pellucid (schizogenous) glands contain- ing strong-scented oils
Leaves petiolate or sessile; leaves and phyllaries sparsely tomentose to woolly or glabrescent (without schizogenous glands)
Cauline leaves all alternate.
Phyllaries in 1–2 series, equal.
Pappi persistent, either 1 apically plumose bristle (plus short-toothed cups) or 1–12 bristles (often alternating with easily overlooked, laciniate scales)
Pappi falling or persistent (fragile), usually 20–100+ barbellulate or smooth (barbellate in Pericallis ) bristles.
Disc florets (all or mostly) functionally staminate (not producing cypselae)

Phyllary margins not interlocking; ray corollas usually whitish or bluish, pinkish, purplish, or reddish (often proximally pale and distally darker); pappi readily falling, usually of 20–40+ bristles (discs; rays sometimes of 2 subulate to setiform scales or 0)
Phyllary margins interlocking; ray corollas usually white (with little, if any, yellow), rarely purplish to reddish; pappi persistent or readily falling, usually of 30–80+ bristles.

Calyculi of (0–)1–8+ bractlets; disc corolla tubes shorter than or equaling throats; style branches stigmatic in 2 lines (stamen filaments usually distally expanded into swollen collars); cypselae 5-ribbed or -angled
Phyllaries in 2–7+ series, unequal to subequal (pappi persistent, bristles usually barbellate, sometimes barbellulate).
Subshrubs or shrubs (clambering, sprawling, or vinelike).
Shrubs (clambering, sprawling, or vinelike); rays pale rose-purple to pale pink (Atlantic coastal plain)
Subshrubs or shrubs (not clambering, sprawling, or vinelike); rays white, pink, red-purple, purple, or violet.
Plants often thorny (thorns green); rays white; disc corolla veins orange, resinous
Plants not thorny; rays white, pink, red-purple, purple, or violet; disc corolla veins not orange-resinous.
Stems, leaves, and phyllaries resinous; leaf margins entire; phyllaries 18–24, midnerves expanded, faces glabrous

Stems and phyllaries not resinous (leaves sometimes resinous in Hazardia ); leaf margins entire or toothed or serrate (spinulose or bristly); phyllaries (15–)20–90+, midnerves not expanded, faces glabrous or hairy, sometimes stipitate-glandular.
Ray florets neuter; cypselae cuneiform to linear, not compressed
Ray florets bisexual, fertile; cypselae obscurely cordate, deltoid, ovoid, ellipsoid, oblong, obovoid, cylindro-obconic, fusiform, or linear, usually ± compressed.
Cypselae dimorphic (ray 3-sided, disc compressed), obscurely cordate, ellipsoid, oblong, or obovoid
Cypselae monomorphic (usually ± compressed), deltoid, ovoid, obovoid, cylindro-obconic, fusiform, or linear.
Cypselae 7–10-nerved
Cypselae 2–5-ribbed or -nerved.
Phyllaries in 5–9 series, not keeled; pappi reddish brown
Phyllaries in 2–6 series, keeled; pappi stramineous to tawny.
Cypselae flattened, 2–3(–4)-nerved; pappi of outer, shorter bristles or scales plus inner, longer bristles
Cypselae compressed, 4–5-ribbed; pappi of ± unequal bristles
Annuals, biennials, or perennials.
Annuals or biennials.
Disc corolla veins orange-resinous.
Heads borne singly
Heads usually in corymbiform or paniculiform arrays, sometimes borne singly.
Disc corolla throats slightly indurate and inflated
Disc corolla throats narrowly funnelform (not indurate and inflated).

Leaf faces often stipitate-glandular or gland-dotted; phyllaries lacking orange to brown midnerves; cypselae densely sericeous, ± strigillose, or glabrous, often stipitate-glandular and/or gland-dotted
Leaf faces eglandular; phyllaries with orange to brownish midnerves; cypselae glabrous or strigillose, eglandular
Disc corolla veins not orange-resinous.
Pappus bristles usually 5
Pappus bristles usually 20–80+ (ray sometimes 0).
Stems glabrous (or distally hairy in lines only), eglandular; ray florets 90– 110 in 4–5 series (laminae filiform)
Stems glabrous or hairy, often stipitate-glandular as well; ray florets (4–)7–80 in 1 series (laminae usually strap-shaped).
Heads in corymbiform arrays; phyllaries in 2–3 series; ray pappi none

Heads usually borne singly (at ends of branches, leafy stems, or scapi-form peduncles), sometimes in cymiform or corymbiform arrays; phyllaries in 3–12+ series; ray pappi usually present (usually none in Arida ).
Cypselae 2(–3)-nerved
Cypselae smooth (at most obscurely nerved) or 4–13-ribbed or -nerved per face.
Leaves deeply 1–-2-pinnatifid (some or all lobes or teeth acute and bristle-tipped)
Leaves usually entire, toothed, or lobed (if 1–2-pinnatifid, teeth or lobes often rounded, sometimes apiculate, mostly not bristle-tipped).
Cypselae ± obconic, not compressed, smooth (at most obscurely nerved); pappus bristles distinct or basally connate, tan to reddish
Cypselae linear to narrowly obovoid or narrowly oblong, 4–13-ribbed or -nerved; pappus bristles distinct, white to tawny.
Plants hairy, sometimes stipitate-glandular; leaves entire or toothed; ray pappi of 40–50 bristles

Plants glabrous and leaves entire or toothed (ciliate or teeth bristle-tipped or apiculate), or plants hairy, sometimes stipitate-glandular, and leaves 1–2-pinnatifid; ray pappi usually 0 (if 20–30 bristles, leaves 1–2-pinnatifid)
Perennials.

Plants colonial; stems branched, lateral branches strongly ascending, commonly modified to green thorns; leaves early withering; phyllaries (1–)3(–5)-nerved (usually wet sites in arid, sw United States)
Plants sometimes colonial; stems single or clustered, simple or branched (not becoming thorny); at least distal leaves persistent through flowering; phyllaries usually 1-nerved, seldom 3-nerved.
Cypselae usually obconic or obovoid, sometimes lanceoloid, flattened or compressed, margins ribbed (sometimes also 1–2 nerves on faces).
Leaves cauline; phyllaries keeled.

Plants 10–160 cm, minutely stipitate-glandular distally; proximal leaves withering by flowering, proximalmost scalelike, cauline distally increasing in size to mid stems, mid and distal blades lanceolate or lance-ovate to elliptic; heads in racemiform or corymbiform arrays (pappi of outer, shorter and inner, longer bristles in 3 series)

Plants 4–30(–70) cm, sometimes stipitate-glandular; leaves persistent to flowering, mostly equal in size and shape, blades spatulate (proximal), linear, narrowly oblong, or elliptic-lanceolate; heads borne singly or in 2s or 3s, or in corymbiform arrays
Leaves basal and/or cauline; phyllaries not keeled.
Leaf faces eglandular; corolla lobes lanceolate
Leaf faces often gland-dotted; corolla lobes deltate or lance-deltate.

Plants rhizomatous, sometimes taprooted; heads borne singly or in corymbiform arrays; leaves entire, ± dentate, or pinnatifid; phyllaries equal or unequal, 1–3-nerved (nerves golden-resinous); disc corolla throats usually tubular, sometimes strongly inflated-indurate; cypselae glabrous, strigose, or sericeous
Cypseale ± narrowly obconic, obovoid, oblanceoloid, ellipsoid, lanceoloid, or fusiform, to cylindric or linear, ± compressed or terete, usually 3–12+-nerved or -ribbed on faces (margins not ribbed).
Cypselae ± dimorphic (ray 3-sided and rounded abaxially, disc ± compressed); pappi of relatively coarse (± flattened) bristles.
Stems simple; leaves mostly basal, margins serrate or serrulate; involucres depressed-hemispheric; cypselae 3–9-ribbed per face; pappus bristles coarsely barbellate

Stems usually branched; leaves basal (persistent or withering by flowering) and cauline (distally ± reduced) or mostly cauline, margins pinnately lobed or pinnatifid, toothed, or entire; involucres turbinate, campanulate, or hemispheric; cypselae 8–13-nerved per face; pappus bristles barbellulate
Cypselae monomorphic; pappi of relatively fine bristles.
Anther bases tailed
Anther bases rounded, obtuse, or acute (not tailed).
Plants rhizomatous, sometimes with caudices; heads usually in paniculiform or racemiform arrays, rarely borne singly.
Stems spreading-hirsute, eglandular; heads in narrow wand-shaped, paniculiform arrays; phyllary midribs translucent and swollen; rays 7–9 (corollas white to pale cream)

Stems usually glabrous, often distally hairy in lines, sometimes ± densely hairy, sometimes distally stipitate-glandular; heads in ± open or dense (not wand-shaped), paniculiform arrays; phyllary midnerves not translucent and swollen; rays 8–75 (corollas white, pink, blue, or purple).
Phyllaries usually unequal, sometimes subequal, proximally indurate, distally with defined green zones, sometimes distally herbaceous or outer wholly foliaceous, sometimes stipitate-glandular
Phyllaries subequal, herbaceous (without definite distal green zones, not foliaceous), stipitate-glandular.

Stems ± densely villous; leaves cauline, blades 1-nerved (venation reticulate), lanceolate to elliptic, abaxial faces glabrate to ± strigose, adaxial sparsely villous (distal stipitate-glandular); phyllaries often purplish, apices of outer acuminate; cold, wet soils, montane and boreal North America

Stems glabrous; leaves basal and cauline, blades 3-nerved, linear, faces glabrous (distal stipitate-glandular); phyllaries green, apices of outer acute; damp, alkaline areas, deserts and dry prairies, w North America
Plants taprooted, with caudices, or rhizomatous; heads usually in corymbiform (or flat-topped, racemiform) arrays or borne singly, sometimes grouped in loose, corymbiform arrays.

Plants usually tapooted, sometimes with caudices (plus also rhizomatous from fibrous roots in Chaetopappa ); stems usually 1 (sometimes 2–5+ in clumps), branched or simple; heads borne singly or in loose, corymbiform arrays.
Stems and leaves usually densely white-tomentose, sometimes glabrate; ray florets neuter; cypselae cuneiform or linear; pappi reddish to brownish (bristles relatively coarse, California)
Stems and leaves glabrous, glabrate, canescent, villous, or tomentose; ray florets pistillate, fertile; cypselae fusiform, cylindric, obovoid, or linear; pappi hyaline or white to tawny.
Stems simple; leaf margins entire; phyllaries mostly foliaceous (margins sometimes proximally indurate); rays white (maturing or drying bluish or purplish).
Leaves basal and cauline (crowded), blades 1-nerved, linear-oblanceolate to lanceolate; phyllaries not keeled; cypselae 5-nerved
Leaves mostly basal (rosettes), blades 3-nerved, linear to oblanceolate; phyllaries often ± keeled; cypselae 5–10-nerved (nerves raised)

Stems mostly simple (scapiform); leaves mostly basal (rosettes, often marcescent), margins entire or irregularly serrate (teeth apiculate or ± spinulose); phyllaries squarrose; cypselae 8–10-ribbed (canyons, rock faces, Utah)
Stems mostly branched; leaves basal and cauline, margins entire or toothed (teeth spinose-tipped); phyllaries appressed, spreading, or reflexed; cypselae 4-nerved, 4–6-ribbed, or smooth.
Stems mostly single; cauline leaf blades lanceolate to oblan- ceolate; phyllaries not keeled
Stems clustered; cauline leaf blades usually spatulate to obovate or oblong, rarely elliptic; phyllaries keeled
Plants rhizomatous or with caudices; stems 1–5+, usually simple; heads usually in corymbiform arrays, sometimes borne singly (then plants long-rhizomatous, rays pink).
Phyllaries flat, not keeled, midveins orange-resinous or swollen and translucent.
Plants 40–200 cm; leaves basal (withering, reduced) and cauline, blades 1-nerved, lanceolate to elliptic; phyllary midveins orange-resinous; rays 2–10(–16)

Plants 10–40 cm; leaves basal (persistent, well developed) and cauline (reduced), blades usually 1-nerved, sometimes ± 3-nerved, linear to linear-lanceolate, phyllary midveins swollen, translucent; ray florets 10–20
Phyllaries ± rounded, sometimes ± keeled, midveins not swollen.

Rhizomes with swollen apical buds; heads in ± loose, corymbiform arrays or borne singly (nodding in bud); phyllaries lance-ovate to linear (membranous, proximally not indurate, green along midnerves); cypselae 5–8-nerved (lateral 2 thicker), ± densely gland-dotted (e North America)

Rhizomes none or not apically swollen; heads in corymbiform arrays (erect in bud); phyllaries ovate, oblong, lanceolate, or linear-lanceolate (proximally indurate, distally with sharply delimited green apical zones); cypselae 7–12(–18)-nerved, eglandular.
Involucres cylindric; rays 1–6, white; disc corollas white or cream; cypselae ± densely strigose
Involucres cylindro-campanulate or campanulate; rays 5–60, white to purple; disc corollas yellow; cypselae glabrous or ± densely strigillose.

Stems and leaves usually stipitate-glandular, sometimes eglandular and glaucous; leaves mostly cauline, entire or spinulose-serrate, glabrous or scabrellous; phyllaries usually keeled, sometimes rounded, apices acute to long-acuminate; rays 8–27; disc corolla tubes shorter than throats (w Cordilleras)

Stems and leaves usually eglandular, sometimes stipitate-glandular (e North America only), not glaucous; leaves basal and/or cauline, serrate (teeth sometimes spinose, then blades linear, grasslike, se North America) or entire, hairy or glabrous; phyllaries usually rounded, sometimes keeled, apices obtuse to acute; rays 5–60; disc corolla tubes shorter or longer than throats
Leaves opposite (at least proximally, or if mostly basal and subopposite or alternate, cypselae obcompressed, each shed with a subtending, linear, membranous scale).
Leaves and/or phyllaries dotted or streaked with pellucid (schizogenous) glands containing strong-scented oils.
Annuals or perennials; ray florets borne on bases of subtending phyllaries; style branches of bisexual disc florets knob-like
Subshrubs or shrubs; ray florets borne on receptacles; style branches of bisexual disc florets linear

Leaves and/or phyllaries not dotted or streaked (never with pellucid, schizogenous glands containing strong-scented oils, plants sometimes with sessile or stipitate, surface glands and may be otherwise strong-scented).
Leaves (somewhat succulent) sessile or nearly so, filiform to linear, margins entire; phyllaries 2–5 in 1 series

Leaves (seldom succulent) usually petiolate, sometimes ± sessile, blades cordate, deltate, elliptic, lanceolate, narrowly trullate, linear, oblanceolate, oblong, obovate, ovate, cuneate, or spatulate, margins entire, toothed, or distally 3-lobed; phyllaries 5–23 in 1–3 series.
Leaves all or nearly all opposite (distalmost cauline sometimes alternate and usually smaller).
Phyllaries 8–23 in (1–)2 series (subequal); pappi persistent, of 10–50 bristles
Phyllaries 14–18+ in ± 3 series (unequal); pappi fragile, of 6–8+ bristles
Leaves alternate and either proximal opposite or leaves mostly basal (sometimes subopposite).
Phyllaries 8–22 in 2–3 series; cypselae obcompressed (each shed together with a subtending, linear, membranous scale, margins ciliate); pappi of distinct bristles
Phyllaries 5–8 in 1 series; cypselae narrowly obconic, clavate, or fusiform (margins not ciliate); pappi of basally connate or coherent bristles
Leaves all alternate.
Style-branch appendages usually penicillate or essentially 0.
Phyllaries in (2–)3–7+ series, unequal to subequal (distinct, calyculi 0); pappi of (± coarse) barbellate bristles.
Annuals (pilosulous to hispid and stipitate-glandular, viscid); involucres 3–8 mm diam.; ray laminae 2–5(–7) mm
Perennials; involucres 10–40 mm diam.; ray laminae 10–30+ mm
Phyllaries in 1–2 series, equal to subequal (sometimes coherent, often subtended by calyculi); pappi of (fine) smooth or barbellulate bristles.
Shrubs or vines.
Vines (usually ± twining and climbing; corollas orange to ± brick-red; Florida)
Shrubs.
Leaves (or lobes) linear (± evenly distributed)
Leaves lance-elliptic or lanceolate to lance-linear (clustered distally on branches; Arizona and New Mexico)
Annuals, biennials, perennials, or subshrubs.
Annuals.
Receptacles dome-shaped to conic (heights equaling or greater than diameters)
Receptacles flat to convex (sometimes ± dome-shaped in Tephroseris ).
Style branches: stigmatic areas continuous (stamen filaments cylindric, not distally expanded)
Style branches: stigmatic in 2 lines (stamen filaments distally expanded into swollen collars).
Leaves basal and/or cauline (roots often fleshy and seldom branched and/or leaf margins with many callous denticles)
Leaves basal and cauline (roots seldom fleshy, often branched; leaf margins with few or no callous denticles)
Biennials, perennials, or subshrubs.
Disc florets (all or mostly) functionally staminate (not producing cypselae)
Disc florets (all or mostly) bisexual, fertile.
Style branches: stigmatic in 2 lines (stamen filaments usually distally expanded into swollen collars).
Leaves basal and/or cauline (roots often fleshy and seldom branched and/or leaf margins with relatively many callous denticles)
Leaves basal and cauline (roots seldom fleshy, often branched; leaf margins with relatively few or no callous denticles)
Style branches: stigmatic areas continuous (stamen filaments cylindric, not distally expanded).
Petiole bases usually dilated (sheathing stems); laminae of ray corollas orange to orange-yellow or brick-red (20–50 mm); pappi reddish (Maryland)
Petiole bases rarely dilated (except Doronicum and Sino senecio ); laminae of ray corollas usually yellow, sometimes yellow-orange or orange; pappi white or stramineous to brownish.
Phyllaries in 2–3+ series, margins seldom scarious (often ciliate); rays 21–40+ (ray cypselae often epappose)
Phyllaries in (1–)2 series, margins ± scarious (seldom ciliate); rays mostly 5, 8, 13, or 21.
Leaf blades (at least proximal) suborbiculate (lengths mostly 1–1.5 times widths and plants 60–300 cm); corolla tubes usually glandular-puberulent (s Arizona)
Leaf blades seldom suborbiculate (lengths mostly 3–10+ times widths; if suborbiculate, plants 3–60+ cm); corolla tubes seldom, if ever, glandular-puberulent.
Leaf blades pinnately nerved, lanceolate, linear-oblanceolate, oblanceolate, ovate, or subrhombic
Leaf blades palmately or subpalmately nerved, ovate to subreniform (British Columbia)
Style-branch appendages usually deltate to lanceolate, seldom penicillate.
Subshrubs or shrubs.
Phyllaries unequal and all disposed in vertical ranks.
Leaves basal and cauline, blades 3–5-nerved (veins raised, parallel)
Leaves cauline, blades 1-nerved (sometimes with 1–2 fainter lateral pairs, not raised and parallel).
Involucres cylindric, 5–6 mm; phyllaries 8–12, stramineous, flat, midnerves orange-resinous; rays 1–3; disc florets 2–5; cypselae densely strigoso- sericeous

Involucres cylindric, obconic, or hemispheric, 4–15 mm; phyllaries 13–30, green to tan, flat to keeled, midnerves sometimes evident, sometimes enlarged subapically and glandular (not orange-resinous); rays (1–)6–8; disc florets 4–15; cypselae glabrous or densely hairy
Phyllaries equal or unequal and usually disposed in spirals.
Plants spinescent (at least with age)
Plants not spinescent.
Basal leaves pinnatifid (lobes bristle-tipped); pappus bristles basally flattened
Basal leaves not pinnatifid; pappus bristles not basally flattened.
Leaves entire or toothed (bases clasping or subclasping); heads usually in spiciform, racemiform, paniculiform, subumbelliform, or corymbiform arrays, rarely borne singly.

Leaves (teeth not bristly) densely short-woolly (hairs flagelliform); heads in subumbelliform to paniculiform arrays; phyllaries in 3–5 series; pappi of outer, triangular scales plus 20–40 inner bristles in (2–)3 series; e North America
Leaves entire (bases not clasping); heads borne singly or in cymiform, spiciform, corymbiform, or racemiform (sometimes paniculiform or thyrsiform) arrays.
Shrubs.
Involucres hemispheric, obconic, or cylindric; disc corolla lobes equal; cypselae prismatic
Involucres turbinate; disc corolla lobes unequal; cypselae ± turbinate
Subshrubs.
Stems prostrate to erect, mat-forming, branched; leaves cauline (crowded); heads borne singly

Stems erect, not mat-forming, branched or simple; leaves basal and cauline or mostly cauline (then not crowded); heads in spiciform, racemiform, or corymbiform arrays, or glomerate and/or pedunculate-solitary in flat-topped or multi-storied, corymbiform arrays.
Plants stoutly taprooted; leaves 1-nerved, oblanceolate, eglandular or obscurely gland-dotted; heads (not glomerate) in racemiform or loose, spiciform or corymbiform arrays
Annuals, biennials, or perennials.
Pappi of easily overlooked setae or scales plus inner, longer bristles in 2+ series.

Plants taprooted or with simple caudices (and fibrous-rooted); heads borne singly or in 2s or 3s; phyllaries in 2–3 series, equal or subequal, flat, usually 1–3-nerved (nerves golden-resinous); cypselae 2-nerved, not resinous

Plants taprooted, rhizomatous, or with branched caudices; heads usually in corymbiform, ± paniculiform, or subumbelliform arrays, sometimes borne singly; phyllaries in 3–5 series, unequal, usually thickened or keeled (not in Bradburia ), 1-nerved (nerves not golden-resinous); cypselae smooth or 1–14-nerved or -ribbed, nerves or ribs sometimes resinous.
Stems and leaves silky-sericeous, rarely glabrate; leaves sessile, blades 3–11-parallel-nerved (nerves sunken), linear to lanceolate or ovate (often grasslike), margins entire; involucres turbinate

Stems and leaves whitish-strigose, pilose, or hispid, or arachnose to woolly (hairs flagelliform, soft), or glabrous; leaves sessile or basal petiolate, blades usually 1-nerved (veins reticulate, raised abaxially), spatulate, ovate-oblanceolate, ovate, elliptic, elliptic-oblong, oblanceolate, linear-lanceolate, or (usually distal) linear, margins entire, serrate, or dentate (sometimes coarsely ciliate); involucres campanulate or turbinate.
Plants proximally woolly, distally arachnose or pilose (hairs flagelliform); basal leaves sessile
Plants sparsely to ± densely hispid, strigose, or pilose (hairs not flagelliform); basal leaves petiolate.

Perennials (taproots relatively short and/or caudices woody); basal petioles ciliate; cauline leaves much reduced distally, not clasping; heads borne singly or in lax, paniculiform arrays; cypselae monomorphic, ray pappi of outer, shorter, setiform scales or bristles plus inner, longer bristles

Perennials (caudices woody); basal petioles long-strigoso-ciliate; cauline leaves ± reduced distally, sometimes clasping or subclasping; heads borne singly or in corymbiform, sometimes paniculiform arrays; cypselae dimorphic or monomorphic, ray pappi 0, or of outer, linear-lanceolate scales plus inner, longer bristles
Pappi of bristles in 1–4 series (seldom with notably shorter bristles, scales, or setae).
Cypselae dimorphic (rays often ± 3-angled, discs ± compressed).
Heads borne singly or in corymbiform arrays (peduncles not cobwebby); involucres 4–10 mm; disc corolla throats gradually ampliate, ± funnelform; style-branch appendages lanceolate

Heads borne singly or (2–3) in paniculiform or subcorymbiform-cymiform arrays (peduncles often cobwebby); involucres 7–16 mm; disc corolla throats abruptly ampliate, funnelform; style-branch appendages deltate
Cypselae monomorphic (all ± compressed or all ± 3-angled).
Leaves 3-nerved (nerves ± parallel), faces thin-arachnose (in minute, abaxial lacunae)
Leaves usually 1-nerved (sometimes 1–5-nerved), faces glabrous or ± hairy (not thin-arachnose in abaxial lacunae).
Cypselae compressed, each edge 1-nerved
Cypselae sometimes ± compressed, each edge not 1-nerved.
Annuals.
Heads borne singly (at tips of branches); involucres eglandular; cypselae oblanceoloid or fusiform and (3–)5-ribbed or -nerved.
Involucres campanulate to turbinate; phyllaries equal or subequal; cypselae oblanceoloid, 3–5-nerved, not beaked; pappus bristles (3–)5–20 (usually in multiples of 5) in 1 series
Involucres ± cylindric to turbinate or obconic; phyllaries unequal; cypselae ± fusiform, 5-nerved, beaked; pappus bristles (12–)30–40 in (1–)2 series (outer shorter)
Heads borne singly or in corymbiform arrays; involucres glandular; cypselae clavate and 3-nerved or obconic and obscurely nerved.
Disc florets functionally staminate
Disc florets bisexual, fertile (corollas of peripheral florets some- times palmately expanded, resembling rays)
Perennials.
Heads usually glomerate and/or sometimes pedunculate-solitary in flat-topped or multi- storied, corymbiform arrays
Heads borne singly or in spiciform, racemiform, paniculiform, or corymbiform arrays (if glomerate, not in flat-topped, corymbiform arrays).
Plants rhizomatous (often colonial); heads in dense corymbiform or paniculiform arrays.

Stems and leaves sometimes stipitate-glandular or gland-dotted; heads in rounded, club-shaped, wand-shaped, or pyramid-shaped paniculiform (often secund) arrays, or in flat-topped, corymbiform arrays; involucres cylindric to campanulate, 3–12 mm, sometimes stipitate-glandular; phyllary midveins usually swollen, translucent, apices often with green zone, sometimes reflexed; rays 3–15(–21); disc corolla lobes lanceolate, erect to reflexed, style-branch appendages triangular; cypselae obconic, sometimes ± compressed, 5–8-nerved

Stems and leaves stipitate-glandular; heads in dense, flat-topped, corymbiform arrays; involucres campanulate to hemispheric, 10–11 mm, stipitate-glandular; phyllary midveins not swollen, apices green-tipped and spreading-reflexed; rays 12–20; disc corolla lobes triangular, spreading, style-branch appendages linear; cypselae fusiform, distinctly compressed, 12–16-nerved (nerves whitish, raised; w United States)

Plants usually taprooted or with caudices, sometimes also from spreading roots (stems single or clustered); heads usually borne singly, sometimes (2–5) in loose, corymbiform, cymiform, or paniculiform arrays, or in spiciform, racemiform, paniculiform, or corymbiform arrays, or glomerate (some Oönopsis ).

Heads usually in rounded, club-shaped, wand-shaped, or pyramid-shaped, paniculiform (often secund) arrays, or flat-topped, corymbiform arrays, or in spiciform, racemiform, or cymiform arrays, sometimes borne singly.

Plants with caudices (stems clustered); leaves basal and cauline; heads in rounded, club-shaped, wand-shaped, or pyramid-shaped paniculiform (often secund) arrays, or flat-topped, corymbiform arrays; involucres campanulate to cylindric, 3–12 mm; phyllary midveins usually swollen and translucent; cypselae 5–8-nerved

Plants taprooted; leaves mostly cauline; heads usually in spiciform, racemiform, or cymiform arrays, sometimes borne singly; involucres campanulate, 11–13 mm; phyllary midveins not swollen; cypselae 4–5-nerved; California, Oregon
Heads borne singly or (2–15) in spiciform, racemiform, paniculiform, or corymbiform arrays.
Pappi brownish.

Stems and leaves glabrous or sparsely tomentose, eglandular; leaves basal (usually withering by flowering) and cauline, blades narrowly oblanceolate to lanceolate or linear, margins entire; heads borne singly, or (2–12) in glomerules or in loose, corymbiform arrays (subtended by little-reduced distal leaves); rays 6–25; cypselae prismatic or narrowly turbinate

Stems and leaves loosely tomentose to woolly, sometimes gland-dotted or stipitate-glandular; leaves basal (persistent) and cauline, basal blades oblanceolate to elliptic or linear, cauline lanceolate, margins entire, spinulose-dentate or -serrate, or shallowly laciniate; heads borne singly or (2–15, ± sessile) in racemiform, spiciform, or loose, corymbiform arrays (at ends of scapiform stems or peduncles); rays 10–80; cypselae subcylindric-fusiform
Pappi whitish or stramineous.
Plants 1–2 cm (± pulvinate), not mat-forming; leaves 1-nerved; heads ± sessile; phyllary margins ± scarious
Plants 1–30(–60) cm, sometimes mat-forming; leaves 1–5-nerved; margins of outer phyllaries herbaceous (proximally indurate).

Stems eglandular or stipitate-glandular, sometimes resinous; leaf margins entire, faces glabrous, scabrous, villous, or lanate, usually stipitate-glandular, sometimes eglandular; phyllaries unequal; rays 5–17; cypselae usually sericeous, sometimes glabrous

Stems densely stipitate-glandular (viscid); leaf margins entire, toothed, or lobed, faces glabrous or scabrous, sometimes stipitate-glandular; phyllaries subequal (outer foliaceous); rays 11–23(–35); cypselae glabrous or villous
Leaves and/or phyllaries dotted or streaked with pellucid (schizogenous) glands containing strong-scented oils.
Leaves opposite (blade margins proximally bristly-ciliate; ray florets borne on bases of subtending phyllaries; style branches of bisexual florets knob-like)
Phyllaries distinct to bases or nearly so.
Rays yellow to orange (pappus scales multiaristate)
Rays whitish with pinkish or purplish stripes (pappi of scales plus bristles)
Phyllaries ± connate 1 / 3 – 7 / 8 + their lengths (margins of outer sometimes distinct to bases).
Calyculi 0; pappi of 2–5(–10) scales in ± 1 series (usually 0–5+ oblong to lanceolate, erose-truncate to laciniate, plus 0–2+, longer, subulate or aristate, some or all sometimes connate)
Calyculi usually of (1–)5–8(–22) bractlets, rarely 0; pappi usually of 8–20 scales in 2 series (rarely coroniform).
Bractlets of calyculi subulate or pectinate
Bractlets of calyculi deltate to subulate, not pectinate.
Plants (20–)30–70+ cm; involucres (7–18 ×) 5–12 mm; phyllaries weakly connate 1 / 3 – 2 / 3 their lengths
Plants mostly (1–)5–30 cm; involucres (4–6 ×) 2–7 mm; phyllaries strongly connate 2 / 3 – 7 / 8 their lengths (margins of outer sometimes distinct to bases)

Leaves and phyllaries rarely dotted or streaked (never with pellucid, schizogenous glands containing strong-scented oils, plants sometimes with sessile or stipitate, surface glands, sometimes strong-scented).
Leaves opposite, or proximal opposite (sometimes 2–3+ pairs) and distal alternate.
Cypselae compressed or flattened, usually callous-margined and ± ciliate.
Phyllaries connate 2 / 3 + their lengths
Phyllaries distinct to bases.

Annuals, perennials, subshrubs, or shrubs, 2–45(–75) cm (usually glabrous or hairy other than woolly); leaves often lobed; involucres campanulate, cylindric, funnelform, or hemispheric, 3–15 mm diam.; disc florets 5–200+
Annuals 1–3(–5) cm (woolly); involucres campanulate, 3–5 mm diam.; disc florets 7–12+
Cypselae (at least disc) mostly columnar or obpyramidal and 4–5-angled, or clavate, columnar, cylindric, or obconic and 10–15-ribbed (not both compressed and with ± ciliate margins).
Disc cypselae mostly clavate, columnar, cylindric, or obconic and 10–15-ribbed.
Heads in tight, corymbiform aggregations or arrays; rays 0, 1, or 3–5.
Rays 3–5; pappi of 5 erose scales alternating with 5 setiform scales or bristles (sometimes all 10 elements basally connate)
Rays 0 or 1; pappi of 2–4 hyaline scales
Heads borne singly; rays 2–4 or 10–15.
Perennials; pappi of 1–5 scales
Subshrubs or shrubs; pappi of 12–25, or ca. 50 scales.
Rays 10–15; pappi of 12–25 subulate scales in 1 series
Rays 2–4; pappi of ca. 50 setiform scales in 3–4 series
Disc cypselae mostly columnar or obpyramidal and 4–5-angled (sometimes obovoid, smooth in Lasthenia ; 2- or 4-angled in Monolopia ).
Ray laminae ca. 0.5 mm (inconspicuous); disc cypselae 2-angled (pappi of 2–7 scales)
Ray laminae mostly 1–25+ mm (usually conspicuous).
Disc corolla lobes lance-linear, lance-oblong, or linear (equal or unequal).
Disc corollas creamy to bright yellow
Disc corollas pinkish, purplish, or whitish
Disc corolla lobes mostly deltate to lance-deltate or lance-ovate.
Leaves usually sessile, sometimes petiolate; phyllaries distinct or partially connate (pappus scales not notably medially thickened).
Leaves opposite ± throughout, faces usually glabrous or glabrate (sparsely woolly to villous in L. minor and L. platycarpha )
Leaves opposite proximally, distal usually alternate, faces usu- ally densely to sparsely woolly
Leaves usually petiolate; phyllaries distinct (pappus scales usually notably medially thickened).
Phyllaries 4–9(–12, margins often purplish or yellowish)
Phyllaries 6–18+ (margins rarely purplish, not yellowish).
Annuals, biennials, or perennials, 10–80+ cm; leaves all or mostly opposite (if perennials, blades or lobes lanceolate to oblong, 2–20+ mm wide), or all or mostly alternate (proximal opposite)
Perennials, 3–20+ cm; leaves all or mostly opposite (blades or lobes lanceolate to lance-linear, mostly 1–8 mm wide)
Leaves alternate.
Pappi partially of scales (scales subtended by, subtending, or alternating with bristles).
Rays mostly white, sometimes wholly or partially blue, lilac, maroon, pink, purple, or violet.
Phyllary mid-nerves usually orange.

Plants not colonial (stems sometimes ± clustered); stems often stipitate-glandular; basal leaves persistent or withering by flowering; heads borne singly or (2–10) in corymbiform arrays; pappi usually of outer setae or scales plus 5–40(–50) inner bristles

Plants colonial; stems eglandular; basal leaves withering by flowering; heads in corymbiform or diffuse, paniculiform arrays; pappi of 2–3 awns plus shorter bristles or scales, or wholly of minute scales
Phyllary mid-nerves not orange.
Pappi of scales alternating with bristles.
Phyllaries 10–50 in 2–6 series; disc florets 5–25
Phyllaries 10–14 in (1–)2 series; disc florets 28–40
Pappi of scales subtending bristles.
Leaf blades lance-elliptic, linear, oblong, or spatulate
Leaf blades cordate-deltate to orbiculate or polygonally lobed (plants often persisting after cultivation)
Rays mostly yellow to orange, sometimes partially (rarely wholly) blue, brown, lilac, maroon, pink, purple, red, or violet.
Pappi of (25–40) bristles subtending (8–15) subulate scales
Pappi of scales (often setiform, inconspicuous) subtending bristles.
Heads borne singly or in 2s or 3s; phyllaries in 2–3(–4) series, usually 1- or 3-nerved (nerves golden-resinous), equal or subequal; cypselae 2-ribbed (each margin thickened, not resinous)

Heads usually in corymbiform, ± paniculiform, or subumbelliform arrays, sometimes borne singly; phyllaries in 3–5 series, 1-nerved (nerves not golden-resinous), unequal to subequal; cypselae smooth or 1–14-nerved or -ribbed (nerves or ribs sometimes resinous).

Leaves sessile, blades 3–11-parallel-nerved (nerves sunken), mostly lanceolate, linear, or ovate (often grasslike), margins entire, faces usually silky-sericeous, rarely glabrate; involucres turbinate

Leaves sessile or petiolate (basal), blades usually 1-nerved, mostly elliptic, elliptic-oblong, lance-linear, linear, oblanceolate, ovate, ovate-oblanceolate, or spatulate, margins entire, dentate, or serrate (sometimes ciliate), faces usually arachnose, hispid, pilose, strigose, or woolly, sometimes glabrate or glabrous; involucres campanulate, hemispheric, or turbinate.
Anthers not tailed.
Plants proximally woolly, distally arachnose or pilose; basal leaves sessile
Plants sparsely to ± densely hispid, strigose, or pilose; basal leaves petiolate.

Basal leaves: petioles ciliate; cauline leaves much reduced distally (bases not clasping); heads borne singly or in lax, paniculiform arrays; ray pappi of outer, setiform scales (0.3–1 mm) plus 20–35 inner bristles (3–6 mm)

Basal leaves: petioles long-strigoso-ciliate; cauline leaves ± reduced distally (bases sometimes clasping or subclasping); heads usually in corymbiform, sometimes paniculiform, arrays, sometimes borne singly; ray pappi 0, or of outer, linear to linear-lanceolate or triangular scales (0.2–1 mm) plus 30–45 inner bristles (3–11 mm)
Pappi wholly of scales (scales sometimes aristate, not associated with distinct bristles).

Styles (in bisexual, fertile florets) usually distally dilated and ± cylindric, style branches linear (sometimes adhering almost to minutely parted tips or essentially lacking, style-branch appendages essentially none; plants usually persisting after cultivation).
Phyllaries connate 1 / 3 – 3 / 4 their lengths; ray laminae 5-nerved, 4-lobed or -toothed
Phyllaries distinct; ray laminae 4-nerved, 3-lobed or -toothed.

Phyllary appendages entire or lacerate, not fringed; pappi of ± cadu- cous, distally plumose bristles

Phyllary apices spiny or not, not hooked; pappi of basally connate, plumose flattened bristles (“setiform scales”).
Receptacles bristly (bearing setiform scales or “flattened bristles,” becoming fleshy); florets 100–250+
Receptacles not bristly (sometimes paleate, not fleshy); florets 10– 20
Plants not prickly-spiny and thistlelike, phyllary apices not spinose or expanded and fringed.
Phyllaries usually (12–30+) in 3–10+ series, wholly scarious or margins and/or apices notably scarious.
Annuals; pappi persistent; pappus bristles ± plumose
Annuals, biennials, or perennials; pappi readily falling; pappus bristles barbellate to barbellulate.

Heads in spiciform or subcapitate arrays or in glomerules in continuous or interrupted, usually spiciform, sometimes paniculiform, arrays (in terminal glomerules in depauperate plants); cypselae ± papillate (papillae myxogenic) or strigillose (hairs not myxogenic); pappus bristles usually basally connate, readily falling (in groups or rings; distinct in Omalotheca supina )

Heads usually in ± capitate clusters (subtended by leafy bracts) or corymbiform or paniculiform (often bracteate) arrays; cypselae usually glabrous or minutely hairy or papillate (papillae not myxogenic), sometimes minutely roughened and/or with 4–6 longitudinal ridges; pappus bristles distinct (falling separately) or basally coherent (falling in groups or rings).
Involucres narrowly campanulate to cylindric; phyllaries mostly stramineous to brownish, sometimes purplish to pinkish (hyaline, stereomes not glandular)
Involucres narrowly to broadly campanulate to cylindric; phyllaries white, rosy, tawny, or brown (opaque or hyaline, stereomes usually glandular)
Phyllaries in 2–5+ series, ± herbaceous to chartaceous and/or margins and apices not notably scarious.
Style-branch appendages penicillate or essentially 0 (style branches stigmatic to tips).
Heads discoid.

Perennials; cypselae columnar, sometimes arcuate, 8–10-ribbed
Heads disciform (peripheral pistillate florets in 1–10+ series).

Leaves all or mostly cauline
Style-branch appendages deltate to lanceolate or terete to clavate.
Style-branch appendages deltate to lanceolate.

Plants bisexual (some or all florets bisexual), sometimes glutinous (annuals or perennials).

Annuals.

Pappi of (5–)10–80+ barbellulate, barbellate, or plumose bristles (or setiform scales)

Cypselae 8–10-ribbed.

Leaves basal or basal and cauline (cauline mostly sessile).

Corollas all 2-lipped (shrubs)

Phyllaries usually (12–30+) in 3–10+ series, scarious or margins and/or apices usually notably scarious, sometimes (3–10) in 1–2 series.

Heads usually discoid (unisexual or nearly so, staminate or pistillate; plants unisexual or nearly so; predominantly pistillate heads rarely with 1–9 central, functionally staminate florets; predominantly staminate heads rarely with 1–4+ peripheral, pistillate florets; involucres mostly 6–10 mm).

Plants mostly 20–80(–120+) cm; basal leaves usually withering before flow- ering; pappus bristles distinct or basally connate

Pistillate florets fewer than bisexual.
Subshrubs; heads in glomerules in corymbiform arrays; involucres cam- panulate, 4–8 mm

Heads usually in glomerules in continuous or interrupted, usually spiciform, sometimes paniculiform, arrays (in terminal glomerules in depauperate plants); cypselae ± papillate (papilliform hairs myxogenic); pappus bristles basally connate, readily falling (in rings)
Phyllaries in 3–5+ series, usually ± herbaceous to chartaceous, sometimes indurate, margins and/or apices seldom notably scarious.
Leaves and/or phyllaries dotted or streaked with pellucid (schizogenous) glands containing strong-scented oils

Leaves and/or phyllaries rarely dotted or streaked (never with pellucid, schizogenous glands containing strong-scented oils, plants sometimes with sessile or stipitate, surface glands and strong-scented).
Subshrubs, shrubs, or treelets.
Plants unisexual (florets unisexual), often glutinous

Leaf faces gland-dotted (in pits); heads in dense, cymiform arrays

Phyllaries disposed in spirals and equal or unequal.
Shrubs or treelets.

Lepidospartum , in part, shrubs with leaves of flowering stems filiform or acerose to scalelike).

Leaves filiform, margins flat or involute; heads in clusters at branch tips, grouped in cymiform or racemiform arrays; involucres turbinate; disc florets 3–7, corolla lobes unequal (cypselae 1–3 mm)

Stems eglandular; leaves entire.

Heads usually in spiciform, racemiform, corymbiform, or cymiform arrays, rarely borne singly; cypselae monomorphic (terete, subterete, or compressed).

Annuals, biennials, or perennials.
Annuals or biennials.
Heads usually discoid (sometimes radiant in Lessingia ).

Leaf blades rounded-deltate, reniform, rounded-rhombic, or suborbiculate, margins toothed or entire, faces usually lanate, pilose, or tomentose, sometimes glandular-pubescent and/or furfuraceous as well; pappi of 35–150 bristles in 1–4 series

Heads usually disciform.

Annuals; stems erect; heads usually in corymbiform, paniculiform or racemiform arrays, rarely borne singly; disc corollas narrowly funnelform (throats neither inflated nor indurate); pappi of 10–30 barbellate bristles.

Pappus scales not both subulate and plumose.

Shrubs; pappi of 12–30 scales (sometimes with bristles as well).
Phyllaries 4–6, or 8–18, in 2 series, ± equal.
Florets 4–8 (cypselae copiously pilose, hairs white, 4–14 mm, sometimes obscuring pappi)
Florets 12–21 (cypselae hirsute, hairs tawny to reddish, 0.5–1 mm; pappi often of both scales and bristles)
Phyllaries 7–60+ in 3–5 series, mostly unequal.
Phyllaries 40–60+ in 3–5 series (often in vertical ranks)
Phyllaries 7–25 in 3 series.
Involures campanulate, globose, or hemispheric, 4–13 × 7–16 mm; florets 13–45
Involures turbino-cylindric, 4–5.5 × 2–3 mm; florets 3–7 (functionally staminate)
Annuals, biennials, perennials, subshrubs, or shrubs; pappi mostly of 1–12(–20+) scales (scales sometimes subtending 20–100+ bristles; if shrubs, pappus scales 1 or 3–5).
Shrubs (stems ± tomentose; leaf blades obscurely pinnate; heads borne singly or in loose, corymbiform arrays; pappi of 1 or 3–5 scales)
Annuals, biennials, perennials, or subshrubs.

Leaves usually 1–3-pinnate (usually aromatic when crushed); phyllary margins usually notably scarious; style-branch appendages essentially none; pappus scales usually rudimentary (3–5, subulate in Sphaeromeria ).
Annuals; heads discoid
Perennials; heads disciform (peripheral florets pistillate).
Heads usually in lax to dense, corymbiform arrays, rarely borne singly; involucres (3–)5–10 mm diam.; florets 60–300+
Heads usually (8–20+) in tight, capitate arrays; involucres (2–)3–4 mm diam.; florets 30–50+

Leaves usually not lobed, sometimes 1–4-pinnate (seldom notably aromatic when crushed); phyllary margins seldom notably scarious; style-branch appendages mostly deltate to lanceolate or linear; pappus scales usually conspicuous (sometimes associated with bristles).
Phyllaries 25–125 in 3–9 series; pappi of scales only or of 5–20 scales plus 20–100+ bristles.
Phyllary apices often looped, hooked, patent, recurved, straight, or incurved; pappi fragile or readily falling, of 8–15 subulate to setiform scales
Phyllary apices usually erect and straight, sometimes spreading or reflexed; pappi persistent or readily falling, usually of scales plus bristles.

Heads usually in corymbiform, ± paniculiform, or subumbelliform arrays, sometimes borne singly; phyllaries in 3–5 series, unequal, usually thickened or keeled, 1-nerved (nerves not golden-resinous); cypselae 3-angled or 4–12-ribbed
Heads borne singly or in 2s or 3s; phyllaries in 2–3 series, equal or subequal, flat, usually 1–3-nerved (nerves golden-resinous); cypselae 2-nerved
Phyllaries 6–25(–60) in 2–3 series; pappi mostly wholly of scales (usually 5, 10, 15, or 20, subulate-aristate scales in Pentachaeta ).
Cypselae narrowly clavate to oblanceoloid, or columnar to obconic or obpyramidal (lengths usually 3+ times diams., if stouter, usually ± compressed).
Leaves usually sessile, sometimes obscurely petiolate (rarely truly petiolate); pappus scales often aristate, not medially thickened
Leaves usually petiolate (± sessile in some spp. of Chaenactis ); pappus scales sometimes aristate or lacerate, often notably medially thickened.
Pappus scales 4–20, not lacerate (usually erose, sometimes uniaristate)
Pappus scales 5, lacerate (divisions bristlelike)
Cypselae stoutly obconic to obpyramidal (lengths usually 1–2, rarely to 3.5, times diams.).

Phyllaries usually strongly reflexed in fruit; receptacles mostly globose (sometimes with setiform enations); disc corollas often brown-purple to red-brown or tipped with brown-purple to red-brown (tubes much shorter than abruptly much-dilated, urceolate to campanulate throats, lobes often shaggily hairy, hairs ± moniliform).
Stems not winged (receptacles usually with setiform enations; style-branch apices ± attenuate)
Stems often winged (by decurrent leaf bases; receptacles rarely with setiformenations; style-branch apices penicillate or truncate)

Phyllaries mostly erect to spreading in fruit; receptacles flat, conic, domed, hemispheric, or ovoid (smooth or pitted, without setiform enations); disc corollas usually uniformly yellow to cream, sometimes purplish to reddish (tubes much shorter than to about equaling slightly dilated, funnelform to cylindric throats, lobes not shaggily hairy with moniliform hairs).

Leaf blades simple or 1–2-pinnately lobed (lobes mostly filiform, linear, or oblong), ultimate margins entire or toothed, faces glabrous or hairy, usually ± gland-dotted (often in pits); phyllaries persistent (or inner falling), usually (6–)6–30(–40) in 2 series and unequal (outer usually connate), sometimes 28–50 in 2–3 series and subequal (usually spreading to erect in fruit)

Leaf blades mostly oblanceolate to linear or filiform, sometimes lobed, ultimate margins usually entire, sometimes toothed, faces glabrous or ± hairy, eglandular or ± gland-dotted; phyllaries usually persistent, 11–60+ in 2–3 series (mostly spreading to erect in fruit, distinct, herbaceous; outer with or without scarious margins, abaxial faces ± hairy; mid usually same number as, alternating with, and similar to outer, almost always with ± scarious margins; inner narrower than others, margins scarious)
